awd_titl_txt: Geoinformatics Facilities Support:  Integrated Data Collections for the Earth & Ocean Sciences:  The Marine Geoscience Data System and the Geoinformatics for Geochemistry Program
awd_abstract_narration: This Cooperative Agreement creates a community-driven facility that consolidates a number of essential cyberinfrastructure activities in the solid-earth geosciences at the Lamont Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University.  It includes data repositories; author attribution schema; data management, discovery, and visualization tools; web portals and services; and the development and implementation of a sample unique-identifier registration system and database interoperability and metadata standards.  The project also includes the creation of geoscience education and outreach modules and workshops.  Goals of the facility are to serve the data management and discovery needs of the geoscience community and to provide direct public accessibility to NSF-funded data sets and associated data products. To achieve these goals, the collected activities are overseen by an external advisory structure of users and domain scientists in the geoinformatics, geophysics, igneous petrology, geochemistry, sedimentology, hydrothermal vent fluid, and polar geoscience communities and who work in concert with NSF to best serve community needs and monitor project performance.  The broader impacts of the resulting facility and its activities are broad and far-reaching in terms of building infrastructure for science and education in the solid-earth geosciences.  The resulting infrastructure and unified data submission procedures and standards will significantly advance the field of geoinformatics and provide essential tools for discovering data and combining disparate datasets such that more complex scientific problems can be tackled by providing a means to efficiently collect and view and model multiple datasets.  It also provides an important educational tool for students by allowing them to explore large amounts of data in creative ways.

por.por_cntn:
The Interdisciplinary Earth Data Alliance IEDA is a research data facility, funded by the NSF to ensure that the data scientists generate as part of their research in the earth sciences are preserved, remaining findable and openly accessible online and useful for future research endeavors, for education, and for policy makers and the general public. IEDA’s multidisciplinary data resources focus on unique observational data acquired by individual investigators (“long-tail data”) and dedicated data acquisition and sample repository facilities in the Ocean, Earth, and Polar Sciences, specifically in marine geosciences, geochemistry, petrology, and geochronology.

Earth scientists make many different types of observations, measurements, and experiments in the field (on land or at sea) and in laboratories to better understand the past and present state of our planet and the processes that shape it: They measure the speed of seismic waves traveling through the Earth’s interior to unravel its internal structure; they collect rock samples from volcanoes and analyze their chemical composition to understand the magmatic processes that happen deep in the earth; they study sediments collected on land or on the ocean floor to discover remnants of past life and environments. These observations and measurements accumulate into an immense body of data that forms the foundation of new knowledge and discoveries beyond their original purpose.

Scientific innovation depends on open access to data, as does the integrity of research. The NSF therefore funds research data facilities such as IEDA to provide professional services for data storage, data cataloguing, and for making the data discoverable and accessible online in the most meaningful way. IEDA was created as a partnership between the Marine Geoscience Data System (MGDS) and the suite of EarthChem data systems, including the System for Earth Sample Registration (SESAR). These data systems that are scientifically linked in their relevance for studies of the solid Earth had been developed independently at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory (LDEO) in the late 1990 and early 2000s. In 2010, this award provided the funds to convert the separately managed data systems into a community-based facility that would provide a centralized location for the registry of and access to data essential for research in the solid-earth and polar sciences. IEDA operated, maintained, and further developed the core data systems of the MGDS, EarthChem, and SESAR, while also developing new shared services and infrastructure that are used across the systems. Two data systems operated at other institutions joined IEDA during the performance period of this grant: the Academic Seismic Portal @ UTIG and the Library of Experimental Phase Relations (LEPR), both closely aligned with IEDA’s foundational systems.

Operation of the IEDA data facility includes database development and management; development of software tools and utilities that allow users to submit and register their data, to discover and access data, and to visualize and analyze data; manual and automated data quality control, data attribution, and long-term data curation; development and maintenance of web services for machine-to-machine data exchange with other data resources in the solid-earth and polar sciences; and a substantial effort for community outreach and engagement to create awareness of IEDA, to train researchers and students in the use of the systems, and to gather feedback about utility and usability of the systems to ensure that IEDA’s services are aligned with the needs of its users.  

IEDA has established itself as one of the leading data facilities in the Earth sciences in the US as demonstrated in a 2013 EarthCube survey, NSF’s 2016 analysis of Data Management Plans, and in usage statistics that IEDA gathers. It has significantly grown the data holdings that are available to its users, in some systems by orders of magnitude. Thousands of researchers from the US and across the globe have explored and mined IEDA’s data collections and global syntheses of quality-controlled data. The growing number of citations of IEDA data resources in the scientific literature provides evidence that IEDA data have supported a substantial range of studies, led to new discoveries, and helped researchers invent new data-driven approaches. Educators have used IEDA data systems and visualization tools to create course materials and class exercises that have allowed students to explore and analyze multidisciplinary Geoscience data.

IEDA has also contributed substantially to the advancement of cyberinfrastructure in the Earth sciences, engaging in collaborations with computer and information scientists, CI experts, and other data systems and facilities to develop, test, and operationalize new technologies, data standards, and best practices in data management. Among these are the international implementation of the International Geo Sample Number (IGSN), metadata standards for cruises, geophysical data, samples, and geochemical and geochronological data, and web services for a variety of systems and data types. IEDA has also played a leadership role in connecting publishers and data facilities in the Earth Sciences to link data and articles in the scholarly literature.
